children.subject:
Unfortunately I didn't see a lot of salary negotiation resources at Berkeley (someone please correct me if there are workshops and the like)! However, there are lots of great online resources related to this! I will link a couple:

  • https://www.levels.fyi - self-reported salaries for tech companies. Sorted by level (new grad, principal, senior engineer, etc.) in a really easy to see way, so it's good to see your potential career progression
  • https://www.teamblind.com - anonymous forum that is basically all about discussing salaries and offers. Comes with all the negative parts of an anonymous forum, and IMO people on blind appear to have an almost meme-level fixation on TC (total compensation) above everything else in life. But it's a good resource!
  • https://www.glassdoor.com/ - probably the most comprehensive salary database I know. It's available for a lot of companies! Also comes with reviews
  • https://www.kalzumeus.com/2012/01/23/salary-negotiation/ - somewhat famous blog post on salary negotiation. It's really long, but imo extremely eye-opening

Unfortunately I don't know of resources that segment salary by e.g. GPA or membership in an honor society. And I'm not entirely sure how relevant they are to the salary negotiation process, to be honest with you (they might certainly be relevant earlier in the process). But someone who knows more than me can chime in.

Do try to stay rational, and take all advice you hear with a grain of salt. If people know of more potentially trustworthy sources, I would also be interested to know. Good luck! You got this :)
200k is near the upper bound already. 300k is too much imo. I don't think this is credible.
usually you give your expectation in terms of base salary. I think 120k is a good starting place.
^ for Bay Area based tech companies.

Never heard of a $200k total compensation minimum, can anyone else confirm or deny? Not unreasonable for FAANGs in my knowledge, but outside those companies isn't total compensation around $130k to $170k?
anon above was trolling with that.

i was not trolling. if you are not getting at least $200k, you are definitely being lowballed.. by the way, i think it helps all of us to ask for higher compensation, since then compensations will rise all around.

How do you calculate TC? Most new offers I know are in the range $90-140K, 50-100K in stocks, and a 10-30K signing bonus. If you really want to, add $5-6K for healthcare, probably $8-9K for a good 401K match, and maybe $2-3K in misc benefits (transit, etc.). Don't factor in meals, etc.

Based on that, I agree with the above that $130-$170K is a typical range. 

Oh, and the love of anything holy, please do not treat startup options as anything other than $0.

"Oh, and the love of anything holy, please do not treat startup options as anything other than $0. "

Makes you wonder why any new grad would want to join a startup then

You should never join a startup because you're hoping for a big payout. The odds suck, massively. You should join a startup with all the risks associated because it can still be a great opportunity. But financially speaking, you need to value it appropriately.

I *did* join a startup after graduation (employee #7, and I think 2nd non-cofounder engineer -- so pretty early), and my shares turned out fine. I mean, I'm incredibly lucky to have the experience I had. I liked it, the people and the product are great. That was why I did it. Statistically speaking, though...positive exits for startups are generally not that positive for normal employees.  Startup shares are not liquid. You cannot sell them when you need to, even after they vest, and even then they are not on paper worth the value -- for example if you have 0.5% of a 3 mil company, you shares are in theory worth $15,000 but you can't really sell them because the company is not public. In 12 months when part of it vests you maybe own $5K worth of shares..., if you company if bought before all your shares vest then you only get a fraction what you might have planned for. Plus employee stock is the lowest on the totem pole, so unless the rate of return is great you won't see a full multiple. (There's also a thing here where startup shares are typically options which larger company stock are typically RSUs, which has some implications too -- especially if you leave the company.)

I had another offer from a big tech company, but in Seattle (so, yeah, 1 of the big 2. Salary was basically competitive for the bay based on my friends' offers). Assuming I held my shares after vesting, they would be worth more today than my payout from the acquisition, and the tax advantages would have made significant differences. Or maybe I wouldn't have held on so long, but probably would have had a house then....but, hey, zero regrets!

You don't have any guarantees with stock price for a public company, but you will be able to sell it for the price on the (virtual) paper. The point is, you have to value what is guaranteed differently from what is possible. You should hope for, and strive for a fantastic outcome at a startup, but you should not make a financial decision assuming your shares will be worth something.

The highest band i've seen for fb new grad return interns is 260-270 year 1 (due to 100k sign-on), and around 190-200 year 2 onwards. Only "rockstar" interns, those who got Greatly Exceeds ratings or better, got around that, and even for some of those it might have taken some negotiation. Not sure where OP got the 300 figure from.

$100k is WAY too low for a new grad. You should be getting $200k total compensation, at a MINIMUM. And your 3.35 GPA isn't bad at all, it's not good but it's not bad either. I know people who have 3.0 GPA but got $300k total compensation offers because they interned at facebook

I'm a sophomore and my only recruiting experience is with internships so don't quote me on this, but it sounds like you sold yourself way short. Depends on location/company but most Bay Area tech companies are paying 150k+ TC to new grads, with some offers at 200k+ or even 300k+. My experience with recruiters during internship recruiting has been that they're often not on your side. As a general rule, there are some questions that you should dodge whenever asked, and this is prime among them. 

I would recommend answering this with something like "I want something market-competitive, but I don't really have a number in mind. I don't really think it's productive to discuss compensation until you're extending an offer." The advice I've heard repeatedly is to *never* give a number. 

(The same dodging advice applies if they ask you where else you're interviewing, that one's burned me in an interview before.)

I don’t know about minimum total comp. I hate giving 6 figure minimums without simultaneously suggestions we all start canvassing....I am conflicted. That’s why I am here and not engineering full time. ....Anyway...here’s what I will say:

Aim high, but be satisfied that you’ll still be making a good income regardless of outcome. But fight like hell for yourself. You CAN do better than $100K! You should always ask for more than you’ll be 

First, you should come up with a number where you will have no financial concerns on a monthly basis. Consider where you would like to live, what you spend money on, what loans and family obligations you have. In that calculation factor in healthy financial decisions like saving for retirement and the like. Work backwards from there to get a target salary. Don’t be skimpy on yourself, but of course don’t be overly extravagant. This will give you a number that you can have as a goal for your starting salary. Depending on that range (seriously it varies quite widely, and that’s ok!)


In terms of salary negotiations—I think asking people early on for a range is BS. It entirely benefits the employers. They have all the knowledge and experience, you do not. So take the number you came up with and ask for quite a bit more. 

Many companies won’t move much on salary but may move a fair bit on stock. So many sure that if someone says no, you ask about all the other options. 

When negotiating you should try to have a handful of reasons for upping your offer. One of those is that graduating CS is no small feat! This is an amazing place and you worked very hard for the last 4 years - so remember that. Now, I do not think GPA matters much. In terms of software engineering productivity,  especially. I know wicked smart people who can design a great algorithm but are not so good at implementing it and make poor teammates. So consider all your advantages, what specific courses help you? What outside domain knowledge are you bringing to the team? Are you a past TA working on an educational app? That’s helpful! A sports fanatic working on some fantasy app? Etc.
In my experience you’re always walking a bit of a fine line between being confident and cocky. Believe in yourself, the more you do the easier it will be when asking for more. It’s also OK to reference other data points you have. So the links mentioned above are good resources.

A few things to be aware of, if you can: 
* exploding offers are BS and not allowed through the campus career center. If any company has a relationship with campus they are supposed to follow the career center guidelines even if you didn’t find a job via the career center. Look those up, it’s been a while since I read them. :)
* negotiate on timelines, too. You can always ask for more time on an offer, some people won’t give it but at this stage companies can afford to...


Maybe I’ll think of something else but bottom line: always ask for more, but remember how fortunate we are in this position. :)

— that goes for everyone not just OP.
this is the right answer. Don't listen to that guy proclaiming 200k as a lower bound.
170-200k is pretty competitive (G/FB/Unicorn level), and is what you should shoot for.

Go on cs related subreddits (r/csmajors, r/cscareerquestions) and look up your circumstances. You should be able to make a better judgement there as you might (and probably will) someone that was in a similar position to you.

history.content:
This is a question often asked, and instead of making my own answer I think its best to link to a popular outside resource. Here is one I found very compelling:

https://haseebq.com/my-ten-rules-for-negotiating-a-job-offer/

I think one of the biggest factors in the gender pay gap is that women are less likely to negotiate; reading your experience it seems as though you are one of these cases. I really hope you can take everyone's tips to heart and end up with a higher salary!

When asked about expected salary early in the interview process, my stance is that it is best to avoid any numbers. If possible, I want to delay this discussion to after you get an offer, after the company had committed to your hiring somewhat. You can do this with "I expect my salary to be competitive and in line with other companies in the area" or "I am uncomfortable sharing this information at this stage in the interview process". A high number may cause some companies to drop you early, but offers are almost never rescinded after being made because the candidate over-negotiated (although Ive heard rare cases of being lowered).

Of course, maybe you don't want to work for a company so easy to drop you, and would want to avoid wasting time with such companies; in that case setting a high initial bar would be effective.

In either case, it is imperative to understand the salary levels for similar companies in the area. Gather info from other friends also interviewing, amd sites like glassdoor, blind, levels.fyi. Transparency gives employees leverage against their employers, who have much more information and experience about salary at their disposal. In this spirit, I will share my offer; I haven't committed but the offer that I'm pretty likely to take is about $130k TC in a big company at one of their offices in the LA area.

Hi!

As a senior, graduating in CS in May, I have been interviewing with a few companies for software engineering positions. One company asked me what my expected salary was and I said somewhere between 80k and 100k. Afterwards, I thought maybe I sounded like I was selling myself short. I am not in any honors societies, I have a 3.35 total GPA, and only started coding a few years ago. I see on the EECS website the average starting salary is 108k. 

I was pretty caught off-guard when the interviewer asked me that question, so I'd like to be better prepared if it happens again with a different company. Any suggestions would be appreciated. 

PS I'm a woman, and I don't want to perpetuate the gender pay gap!
history.subject: New-Grad Salary Expectations

history.subject: New-Grade Salary Expectations
